awd_titl_txt: Ultra-high Precision Assembly of Aerospace Composite Structures: Fusing Physics-Based and Data-Driven Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Composite structures have increasingly emerged for aerospace and other applications because of their high strength-to-weight ratio, good resistance to harsh environments, and great performance reliability. Because composite structures have nonlinear, anisotropic, and compliant properties as well as inherent manufacturing variability, conventional process modeling and quality control methodologies for metal structure assembling are not adequate to composite components. This award supports fundamental research that integrates physics-guided and machine-learning models to advance ultra-high precision assembly of aerospace composite structures. The research involves seamless integration of physical and digital product connections, data science, advanced statistics, and comprehensive manufacturing knowledge. The research has the potential to minimize the material loss, decrease the production flow time and achieve high productivity and quality control for aerospace manufacturing. The scientific findings from this project may also be extended to other composites demanding industries, e.g., automotive, spacecraft and solar energy, and thus, increase the global competitiveness of the U.S. industry. The interdisciplinary nature of this project will provide students with unique educational and research experiences and cultivate a diverse and qualified workforce cognizant with combined manufacturing and data analytics abilities. In addition, the project will develop new learning modules for an undergraduate core course, recruit and mentor underrepresented students, offer industrial short courses, and develop open-source software for precision assembly, all potentially leading to profound impacts to the society.

This research aims to develop fundamental knowledge and transformative technologies for ultra-high precision assembly of large complex-shaped composite structures by advancing physics-guided machine learning. Specific research activities include: (1) developing digital twin for ultra-high precision assembly of composite structures, (2) conducting physics-constrained active learning with safe exploration and efficient exploitation for experimental design and predictive modeling, (3) studying sparse machine learning for an optimal actuating strategy in composite structures assembly, and (4) analyzing theoretical properties of the methodologies. The project will research small-sized key aerospace structures as well as large-scale carbon fiber reinforced composite fuselage of ultra-high precision, e.g., less than 0.2 mm for a diameter of about 5 m. The methodologies will be computationally and experimentally evaluated in the verification and validation phase. The research outcomes will (1) expand the scientific understanding of engineering-driven data analytics and ultra-high precision quality control theory, (2) bridge the knowledge gap between predictive modeling, active learning, sparse learning, and composite structures assembly, and ultimately, (3) realize the effective all-inclusive integration of machine learning methodologies with advanced manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project sought to advance the precision assembly of composite structures by integrating physics-based and data-driven models. Over the course of the award, the project has made significant contributions to aerospace manufacturing, artificial intelligence, and advanced manufacturing, developing innovative methodologies that improve assembly accuracy, reduce errors, and enhance efficiency.

One of the primary achievements of this project was the development of a reinforcement learning framework for fuselage shape control in aircraft assembly. Traditional methods often struggle with efficiency and adaptability, but this approach utilized a model-free reinforcement learning strategy to enhance performance. By improving sample efficiency and reducing training requirements, the model significantly advanced precision in aerospace manufacturing. Another key innovation was the SmartFixture framework, which leveraged physics-guided reinforcement learning to optimize fixture layout design in manufacturing systems. By directly interacting with Finite Element Analysis simulations, this approach successfully minimized shape deformation in sheet metal and composite parts. Experimental validation demonstrated significant improvements, showcasing the framework’s scalability and generalizability as a powerful alternative to traditional mathematical optimization techniques in manufacturing.

Beyond these technical advancements, the project also contributed to broader scientific understanding by developing physics-constrained active learning methods for experimental design and predictive modeling. These methodologies enhanced the efficiency of composite structure assembly by reducing experimental uncertainty and optimizing actuator forces, ultimately bridging the gap between machine learning and process modeling for engineering applications. The project’s broader impacts extend beyond technical innovation. Over its duration, the research has been widely disseminated through 13 journal publications and 2 conference papers, along with 7 conference presentations and 9 university presentations. These efforts have ensured that the knowledge generated reaches both academic and industrial audiences, fostering collaboration and further research in related fields. In addition to research dissemination, the project has made significant contributions to education and workforce development. Two course modules were developed and updated to incorporate advanced manufacturing and reinforcement learning concepts, enriching the curriculum at Virginia Tech. The project provided direct research opportunities for 4 Ph.D. students, 5 undergraduate researchers, and 4 undergraduate senior design teams, equipping them with hands-on experience in experimental studies, simulation-based modeling, and technical paper writing. By integrating real-world case studies and state-of-the-art methodologies into academic training, the project has played a crucial role in preparing the next generation of engineers and researchers in AI-driven manufacturing.

The outcomes of this project also have significant implications beyond academia. The methodologies developed are applicable to industries such as automotive, shipbuilding, and renewable energy systems, where precision assembly and optimization are critical. By improving manufacturing processes, these innovations contribute to higher quality products, reduced material waste, and increased U.S. competitiveness in advanced manufacturing. The project’s findings also support sustainability efforts by reducing inefficiencies in production, ultimately benefiting the economy and technological advancement.

Through significant research, impactful educational contributions, and industry-relevant advancements, this project has demonstrated how the fusion of physics-based and data-driven models can transform ultra-high precision composite assembly. The work accomplished under this award not only advances academic knowledge but also provides practical solutions that enhance industrial efficiency and competitiveness, ensuring a sustainable impact on both the research community and the manufacturing sector.
